Problem 1

Let X1,…,XnX_1, \ldots, X_nX1​,…,Xn​ be a random sample from a uniform distribution on the interval (θ−1,θ+1)\p{\theta-1, \theta+1}(θ−1,θ+1), where −∞<θ<∞-\infty < \theta < \infty−∞<θ<∞.

  1. Find the method of moment estimator for θ\thetaθ.
  2. Is your estimator in part 1 an unbiased estimator of θ\thetaθ? Justify your answer.
  3. Given the following n=5n = 5n=5 observations of XXX, give a point estimate of θ\thetaθ.
6.617.706.988.367.26\begin{array}{rrrrr} 6.61 & 7.70 & 6.98 & 8.36 & 7.26 \end{array}6.61​7.70​6.98​8.36​7.26​
Solution.

  1. The mean of the uniform distribution is

    E[Xi]=θ,\E\br{X_i} = \theta,E[Xi​]=θ,

    so the method of moment estimate for θ\thetaθ is given by x‾=θ^\mean{x} = \widehat{\theta}x=θ. Thus, the estimator is

    θ^=X‾.\boxed{\widehat{\theta} = \mean{X}}.θ=X​.

  2. Yes. By linearity of expectation,

    E[θ^]=E[1n∑i=1nXi]=1n∑i=1nE[Xi]=θ.\E\br{\widehat{\theta}} = \E\br{\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n X_i} = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n \E\br{X_i} = \theta.E[θ]=E[n1​i=1∑n​Xi​]=n1​i=1∑n​E[Xi​]=θ.

  3. We have

    θ^=x‾=7.382.\boxed{ \widehat{\theta} = \mean{x} = 7.382 }.θ=x=7.382​.

Problem 2

The heart rate (bpm\mathrm{bpm}bpm) of 101010 athletes is measured. The data is given below. Assuming that the distribution from which the data was drawn is normally distributed, find a 95%95\%95% confidence interval for the mean heart rate.

38544236524449506250\begin{array}{rrrrrrrrrr} 38 & 54 & 42 & 36 & 52 & 44 & 49 & 50 & 62 & 50 \end{array}38​54​42​36​52​44​49​50​62​50​
Solution.

Assume that the data was pulled from N(μ,σ2)\mathcal{N}\p{\mu, \sigma^2}N(μ,σ2). Since the population standard deviation is unknown, we need to use a ttt-distribution. Our test statistic is

T=X‾−μS/n∼t(n−1).T = \frac{\mean{X} - \mu}{S/\sqrt{n}} \sim t\p{n-1}.T=S/n​X−μ​∼t(n−1).

Here, SSS is the sample standard deviation and t(n−1)t\p{n-1}t(n−1) is the ttt-distribution with n−1n-1n−1 degrees of freedom. The endpoints for a 100(1−α)%100\p{1 - \alpha}\%100(1−α)% confidence interval are given by

x‾±tα2(n−1)sn,\mean{x} \pm t_{\frac{\alpha}{2}}\p{n-1} \frac{s}{\sqrt{n}},x±t2α​​(n−1)n​s​,

where tα2(n−1)t_{\frac{\alpha}{2}}\p{n-1}t2α​​(n−1) is the 100(1−α2)th100\p{1 - \frac{\alpha}{2}}^{\mathrm{th}}100(1−2α​)th percentile of a t(n−1)t\p{n-1}t(n−1) distribution. For our problem, the parameters are

x‾=47.7,s≈7.8323,n=10,α=0.05.\begin{aligned} \mean{x} &= 47.7, \\ s &\approx 7.8323, n &= 10, \\ \alpha &= 0.05. \end{aligned}xsα​=47.7,≈7.8323,n=0.05.​=10,​

From the textbook's ttt-table,

t0.025(6)=2.262,t_{0.025}\p{6} = 2.262,t0.025​(6)=2.262,

so the endpoints are

47.7±2.262⋅7.832310≈47.7±5.6.47.7 \pm 2.262 \cdot \frac{7.8323}{\sqrt{10}} \approx \boxed{47.7 \pm 5.6}.47.7±2.262⋅10​7.8323​≈47.7±5.6​.

Problem 3

Let x1,…,xnx_1, \ldots, x_nx1​,…,xn​ be an observed sample drawn independently from an exponential distribution, Exp⁡(λ)\operatorname{Exp}\p{\lambda}Exp(λ). Assume that the prior on λ\lambdaλ is characterized by a Gamma distribution, Γ(α,β)\Gamma\p{\alpha, \beta}Γ(α,β), with pdf

π(λ)=βαΓ(α)λα−1e−βλ,0<x<∞.\pi\p{\lambda} = \frac{\beta^\alpha}{\Gamma\p{\alpha}} \lambda^{\alpha-1} e^{-\beta\lambda}, \quad 0 < x < \infty.π(λ)=Γ(α)βα​λα−1e−βλ,0<x<∞.

Note that the pdf of an exponential distribution is given by

f(x)=λe−λx,0<x<∞.f\p{x} = \lambda e^{-\lambda x}, \quad 0 < x < \infty.f(x)=λe−λx,0<x<∞.
  1. Find the posterior distribution for λ\lambdaλ, π(λ | x)\pi\p{\lambda \given x}π(λ∣x).
  2. Calculate the mean of the posterior distribution.
Solution.

  1. The starting point for these types of problems is

    posterior∝likelihood×prior.\mathrm{posterior} \propto \mathrm{likelihood} \times \mathrm{prior}.posterior∝likelihood×prior.

    Here, ∝\propto∝ means that the two things only differ by a constant factor. Here, constant means anything that doesn't depend on λ\lambdaλ. We don't lose any information about the distribution when dropping factors without λ\lambdaλ in them because we can always figure out the normalization constant by integrating with respect to λ\lambdaλ. Actually, we don't even need the normalization constant to figure out the distribution.

    The likelihood is given by

    f(x1,…,xn∣λ)=∏i=1nλe−λxi=λne−λnx‾. f\p{x_1, \ldots, x_n \mid \lambda} = \prod_{i=1}^n \lambda e^{-\lambda x_i} = \lambda^n e^{-\lambda n\mean{x}}.f(x1​,…,xn​∣λ)=i=1∏n​λe−λxi​=λne−λnx.

    The prior is

    π(λ)=βαΓ(α)λα−1e−βλ∝λα−1e−βλ. \pi\p{\lambda} = \frac{\beta^\alpha}{\Gamma\p{\alpha}} \lambda^{\alpha-1} e^{-\beta\lambda} \propto \lambda^{\alpha-1} e^{-\beta\lambda}.π(λ)=Γ(α)βα​λα−1e−βλ∝λα−1e−βλ.

    Putting everything together,

    π(λ | x)∝λne−λnx‾λα−1e−βλ∝λα+n−1e−λ(β+nx‾).\begin{aligned} \pi\p{\lambda \given x} &\propto \lambda^n e^{-\lambda n\mean{x}}\lambda^{\alpha-1} e^{-\beta\lambda} \\ &\propto \lambda^{\alpha+n-1} e^{-\lambda\p{\beta+n\mean{x}}}. \end{aligned}π(λ∣x)​∝λne−λnxλα−1e−βλ∝λα+n−1e−λ(β+nx).​

    By comparing to our known distributions, we see that the posterior distribution is

    Γ(α+n,β+nx‾).\boxed{\Gamma\p{\alpha + n, \beta + n\mean{x}}}.Γ(α+n,β+nx)​.

  2. The mean of a Γ(α,β)\Gamma\p{\alpha, \beta}Γ(α,β) distribution (with the notation in the problem) is αβ\frac{\alpha}{\beta}βα​, so the mean of the posterior distribution is

    α+nβ+nx‾.\boxed{\frac{\alpha + n}{\beta + n\mean{x}}}.β+nxα+n​​.

Problem 4

Assume y1,…,yny_1, \ldots, y_ny1​,…,yn​ are independent observations drawn from N(βxi,σ2)\mathcal{N}\p{\beta x_i, \sigma^2}N(βxi​,σ2). The xix_ixi​'s and σ2\sigma^2σ2 are known constants, and β\betaβ is an unknown parameter which has prior distribution N(β0,τ2)\mathcal{N}\p{\beta_0, \tau^2}N(β0​,τ2), where β0\beta_0β0​ and τ2\tau^2τ2 are known constants. Derive the posterior distribution of β\betaβ.

Solution.

We can use the same approach as in Problem 3. Here, constants are any factors that don't have a β\betaβ in them. The likelihood is

f(y1,…,yn | β)=∏i=1n12πσ2exp⁡(−12σ2(yi−βxi)2)∝∏i=1nexp⁡(−yi22σ2)exp⁡(βxiyiσ2−β2xi22σ2)∝exp⁡(∑i=1n(βxiyiσ2−β2xi22σ2))∝exp⁡(βnxy‾σ2−β2nx2‾2σ2),\begin{aligned} f\p{y_1, \ldots, y_n \given \beta} &= \prod_{i=1}^n \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\sigma^2}} \exp\p{-\frac{1}{2\sigma^2}\p{y_i - \beta x_i}^2} \\ &\propto \prod_{i=1}^n \exp\p{-\frac{y_i^2}{2\sigma^2}} \exp\p{\frac{\beta x_iy_i}{\sigma^2} - \frac{\beta^2x_i^2}{2\sigma^2}} \\ &\propto \exp\p{\sum_{i=1}^n \p{\frac{\beta x_iy_i}{\sigma^2} - \frac{\beta^2x_i^2}{2\sigma^2}}} \\ &\propto \exp\p{\beta \frac{n\mean{xy}}{\sigma^2} - \beta^2 \frac{n\mean{x^2}}{2\sigma^2}}, \end{aligned}f(y1​,…,yn​∣β)​=i=1∏n​2πσ2​1​exp(−2σ21​(yi​−βxi​)2)∝i=1∏n​exp(−2σ2yi2​​)exp(σ2βxi​yi​​−2σ2β2xi2​​)∝exp(i=1∑n​(σ2βxi​yi​​−2σ2β2xi2​​))∝exp(βσ2nxy​​−β22σ2nx2​),​

where I used the shorthands

xy‾=1n∑i=1nxiyi,x2‾=1n∑i=1nxi2.\mean{xy} = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n x_iy_i, \quad \mean{x^2} = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n x_i^2.xy​=n1​i=1∑n​xi​yi​,x2=n1​i=1∑n​xi2​.

Similarly, the prior is

π(β)=12πτ2exp⁡(−12τ2(β−β0)2)∝exp⁡(−β22τ2+2ββ02τ2)exp⁡(−β022τ2)∝exp⁡(−β22τ2+ββ0τ2).\begin{aligned} \pi\p{\beta} &= \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\tau^2}} \exp\p{-\frac{1}{2\tau^2}\p{\beta - \beta_0}^2} \\ &\propto \exp\p{-\frac{\beta^2}{2\tau^2} + \frac{2\beta\beta_0}{2\tau^2}} \exp\p{-\frac{\beta_0^2}{2\tau^2}} \\ &\propto \exp\p{-\frac{\beta^2}{2\tau^2} + \frac{\beta\beta_0}{\tau^2}}. \end{aligned}π(β)​=2πτ2​1​exp(−2τ21​(β−β0​)2)∝exp(−2τ2β2​+2τ22ββ0​​)exp(−2τ2β02​​)∝exp(−2τ2β2​+τ2ββ0​​).​

Putting these together, the posterior pdf is

π(β | y1,…,yn)∝exp⁡(βnxy‾σ2−β2nx2‾2σ2)exp⁡(−β22τ2+ββ0τ2)∝exp⁡(−12(nx2‾σ2+1τ2)β2+(nxy‾σ2+β0τ2)β)∝exp⁡(−12σ2τ2(τ2nx2‾+σ2)β2+1σ2τ2(τ2nxy‾+σ2β0)β).\begin{aligned} \pi\p{\beta \given y_1, \ldots, y_n} &\propto \exp\p{\beta \frac{n\mean{xy}}{\sigma^2} - \beta^2 \frac{n\mean{x^2}}{2\sigma^2}} \exp\p{-\frac{\beta^2}{2\tau^2} + \frac{\beta\beta_0}{\tau^2}} \\ &\propto \exp\p{-\frac{1}{2}\p{\frac{n\mean{x^2}}{\sigma^2} + \frac{1}{\tau^2}}\beta^2 + \p{\frac{n\mean{xy}}{\sigma^2} + \frac{\beta_0}{\tau^2}}\beta} \\ &\propto \exp\p{ - \frac{1}{2\sigma^2\tau^2}\p{\tau^2n\mean{x^2} + \sigma^2}\beta^2 + \frac{1}{\sigma^2\tau^2} \p{\tau^2n\mean{xy} + \sigma^2\beta_0}\beta}. \end{aligned}π(β∣y1​,…,yn​)​∝exp(βσ2nxy​​−β22σ2nx2​)exp(−2τ2β2​+τ2ββ0​​)∝exp(−21​(σ2nx2​+τ21​)β2+(σ2nxy​​+τ2β0​​)β)∝exp(−2σ2τ21​(τ2nx2+σ2)β2+σ2τ21​(τ2nxy​+σ2β0​)β).​

Just from looking at this, we know that the posterior distribution is a normal distribution, so we only need to figure out the mean and variance. Let

a=12σ2τ2(τ2nx2‾+σ2),b=1σ2τ2(τ2nxy‾+σ2β0)\begin{aligned} a &= \frac{1}{2\sigma^2\tau^2}\p{\tau^2n\mean{x^2} + \sigma^2}, \\ b &= \frac{1}{\sigma^2\tau^2} \p{\tau^2n\mean{xy} + \sigma^2\beta_0} \end{aligned}ab​=2σ2τ21​(τ2nx2+σ2),=σ2τ21​(τ2nxy​+σ2β0​)​

and recall that we can complete the square:

exp⁡(−aβ2+bβ)=exp⁡(−a(β−b2a)2+b24a)=exp⁡(−a(β−b2a)2)exp⁡(b24a)∝exp⁡(−a(β−b2a)2),,\begin{aligned} \exp\p{-a\beta^2 + b\beta} &= \exp\p{-a\p{\beta - \frac{b}{2a}}^2 + \frac{b^2}{4a}} \\ &= \exp\p{-a\p{\beta - \frac{b}{2a}}^2} \exp\p{\frac{b^2}{4a}} \\ &\propto \exp\p{-a\p{\beta - \frac{b}{2a}}^2}, \end{aligned},exp(−aβ2+bβ)​=exp(−a(β−2ab​)2+4ab2​)=exp(−a(β−2ab​)2)exp(4ab2​)∝exp(−a(β−2ab​)2),​,

so the mean will be

b2a=1σ2τ2(τ2nxy‾+σ2β0)2⋅12σ2τ2(τ2nx2‾+σ2)=τ2nxy‾+σ2β0τ2nx2‾+σ2.\begin{aligned} \frac{b}{2a} &= \frac{\frac{1}{\sigma^2\tau^2} \p{\tau^2n\mean{xy} + \sigma^2\beta_0}}{2 \cdot \frac{1}{2\sigma^2\tau^2}\p{\tau^2n\mean{x^2} + \sigma^2}} \\ &= \frac{\tau^2n\mean{xy} + \sigma^2\beta_0}{\tau^2n\mean{x^2} + \sigma^2}. \end{aligned}2ab​​=2⋅2σ2τ21​(τ2nx2+σ2)σ2τ21​(τ2nxy​+σ2β0​)​=τ2nx2+σ2τ2nxy​+σ2β0​​.​

For the variance σ12\sigma_1^2σ12​, notice that by looking at the pdf for a normal distribution, it must satisfy 12σ12=a\frac{1}{2\sigma_1^2} = a2σ12​1​=a, so the new variance is

12a=12⋅12σ2τ2(τ2nx2‾+σ2)=σ2τ2τ2nx2‾+σ2.\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{2a} &= \frac{1}{2 \cdot \frac{1}{2\sigma^2\tau^2}\p{\tau^2n\mean{x^2} + \sigma^2}} \\ &= \frac{\sigma^2\tau^2}{\tau^2n\mean{x^2} + \sigma^2}. \end{aligned}2a1​​=2⋅2σ2τ21​(τ2nx2+σ2)1​=τ2nx2+σ2σ2τ2​.​

Thus, the posterior distribution is

N(τ2∑i=1nxiyi+σ2β0τ2∑i=1nxi2+σ2,σ2τ2τ2∑i=1nxi2+σ2).\boxed{\mathcal{N}\p{\frac{\tau^2\sum_{i=1}^n x_iy_i + \sigma^2\beta_0}{\tau^2\sum_{i=1}^n x_i^2 + \sigma^2}, \frac{\sigma^2\tau^2}{\tau^2\sum_{i=1}^n x_i^2 + \sigma^2}}}.N(τ2∑i=1n​xi2​+σ2τ2∑i=1n​xi​yi​+σ2β0​​,τ2∑i=1n​xi2​+σ2σ2τ2​)​.

Problem 5

  1. Let X1,…,XnX_1, \ldots, X_nX1​,…,Xn​ be a random sample from a continuous random variable with pdf
f(x,θ)=θxθ−1,0<x<1,0<θ.f\p{x, \theta} = \theta x^{\theta-1}, \quad 0 < x < 1, \quad 0 < \theta.f(x,θ)=θxθ−1,0<x<1,0<θ.
  1. Find a sufficient statistic YYY for θ\thetaθ.
  2. Show that the maximum likelihood estimator θ^\widehat{\theta}θ is a function of YYY.
  3. Argue that θ^\widehat{\theta}θ is also a sufficient statistic for θ\thetaθ.
Solution.

  1. To find a sufficient statistic, we can factor the likelihood function and eyeball it.

    f(x1,…,xn,θ)=∏i=1nθxiθ−1=θn(∏i=1nxi)θ−1.f\p{x_1, \ldots, x_n, \theta} = \prod_{i=1}^n \theta x_i^{\theta-1} = \theta^n \p{\prod_{i=1}^n x_i}^{\theta-1}.f(x1​,…,xn​,θ)=i=1∏n​θxiθ−1​=θn(i=1∏n​xi​)θ−1.

    So a sufficient statistic is Y=∏i=1nXiY = \prod_{i=1}^n X_iY=∏i=1n​Xi​. We can write down the factorization explicitly:

    φ(y,θ)=θnyθ−1,h(x1,…,xn)=1.\varphi\p{y, \theta} = \theta^n y^{\theta-1}, \quad h\p{x_1, \ldots, x_n} = 1.φ(y,θ)=θnyθ−1,h(x1​,…,xn​)=1.

  2. From our computation above, the log-likelihood function is

    ln⁡L(θ)=nln⁡θ+(θ−1)ln⁡∏i=1nxi.\ln L\p{\theta} = n\ln \theta + \p{\theta-1} \ln \prod_{i=1}^n x_i.lnL(θ)=nlnθ+(θ−1)lni=1∏n​xi​.

    Taking derivatives and solving for θ\thetaθ gives the MLE

    θ^=−nln⁡∏i=1nXi=−nln⁡Y.\widehat{\theta} = -\frac{n}{\ln \prod_{i=1}^n X_i} = -\frac{n}{\ln Y}.θ=−ln∏i=1n​Xi​n​=−lnYn​.

  3. We can solve for YYY in terms of θ^\widehat{\theta}θ:

    Y=exp⁡(−nθ^),Y = \exp\p{-\frac{n}{\widehat{\theta}}},Y=exp(−θn​),

    so plugging this into our factorization,

    f(x1,…,xn,θ)=φ(exp⁡(−nθ^),θ)h(x1,…,xn).f\p{x_1, \ldots, x_n, \theta} = \varphi\p{\exp\p{-\frac{n}{\widehat{\theta}}}, \theta} h\p{x_1, \ldots, x_n}.f(x1​,…,xn​,θ)=φ(exp(−θn​),θ)h(x1​,…,xn​).

    This shows that θ^\widehat{\theta}θ is a sufficient statistic for θ\thetaθ.
